course.subject: CIVL
course.name: Air Quality Control and Management
course.description: Historical and health impact studies related to air pollution. Atmospheric stability and its impact on the transport and dispersion of pollutants. Sources of major air pollutants. Comparison of urban, industrial and transport related air pollution issues, using Hong Kong and Pearl River Delta as examples. Control of stationary and mobile emission sources. Air quality management - framework, policy tools and comparison of different approaches.

reviews.author: WWWW
reviews.title: Insightful course on HK's Air quality monitoring policies, good grade by sacrificing your print budget
reviews.comment_content:
At the beginning:
1.Introduced/ recapped the basics of some air pollutants definition
2. mentioned the history of air pollution (including industrialization/ mentioning The Great Smog of London)
3. Described and provided us some insights on how HK has been performing in terms of monitoring air quality and the major sources of pollutants

Middle part (Personally found this tested in the mid term more often)
4. talked about how different atmospheric motions affect the diffusion of air pollutants
5. Introduced various air quality modeling tools, and mentioned a bit more on Gaussian plume model  (personally would say not super in-depth)

Final
6. Control of different pollutants (like NOx, VOC, SO2...) But the prof has spent most of the time on teaching the control of PM (like collection efficiency of things like cyclones, applications of strokes law...)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Passionate, Approachable, Insightful, Experienced and extremely likely to be a spokesman for Coca-Cola (I wonder if he got paid for that)

I personally have attended some other courses that have also mentioned HK air quality, none of them has given me as much knowledge/ insights as he did. I find his sharing of his opinion on HK's air quality related policy-making very interesting, it was like from a view of the academics that I as a student has not been aware of.

The professor is also super nice, again extremely willing to help you out if you have any problems with any teaching materials/ concepts.  You can meet with him/ find him after class and he will explain things to you in detail if he's available.
reviews.comment_grading:
Really good grading but comes at the expense of your print budget

for exams: OPEN BOOK!!! BRING whatever you like (except computers/ ipads/ phones... electronics except calculator)  
as long as
1.  you print all the notes out ALL!!! (better if you have written some notes on it because at least one of the mc/TnF I remembered its something he has probably only mentioned in class)
2. and print ALL the homework questions + ANSWERS!! (and understand them at least to an application level)

you should be fine for the exam, you may expect one or two questions not as commonly found in the hw, but at least in my exam, that question is not extremely challenging or to be considered as came out of nowhere.

for the maths, only rudimentary level of calculus is needed, but some of the hw that involves proofing, I still find it quite challenging.

others:
for the homework grading, as it covers 20% of the final grade, so try work for it
and for the final report, as the grade was never published, I have no idea.

Grade: A-range
reviews.comment_workload:
Actually, I would say it's not that bad, I'm a bit surprised to find the average of workload is C+ currently.
Around one problem set in one to two weeks time (probably after mid-term you may find it rather intense but the prof was willing to delay the deadline if the majority demanded it), but there are only around 3 to 4 questions. (It happens to me that the difficulty increases per assignment)

For the final report, indeed it has to be submitted right before the exam, but I personally did not spend a lot of time on it (a deadline fighter).  As long as you have attended the classes and reread the notes about HK's situation, plus some online searching (quite a number of reports and news out there already), you will probably have a pretty clear idea of what could be written.

I am also very glad that it has no compulsory literature to be read.

reviews.author: johndoe
reviews.title: 肯俾心機讀就會靚grade
reviews.comment_content:
Midterm 前:
1. Introduction to Air Pollution Control
2. Air Pollution Control Laws, Regulations and Philosophies
3. Meteorology for Air Pollution  Control Engineers

Midterm後:
4. Air Pollutant Concentration Models
5. General Ideas in Air Pollution Control
6. Nature of Particulate Pollutants
7. Control of Primary Particulates
8. Control of Sulfur Oxides
9. Air Quality in Hong Kong
10. Environmentally Sustainable Transportation (EST)

Content偏向environmental, 卻係CIVL嘅elective而唔係CIEV elective, 讀完對香港air pollution同香港政府policy-making嘅愚蠢思維會有更深入了解
reviews.comment_teaching:
Alexis Lau講書雖然真係好多口水野, 有時可能會off topic, 但一啲比較深嘅concept佢都會解得清楚明白(e.g. meteorology, air pollution control device嘅mechanism), lecture完咗之後問佢問題, 佢都肯留低答

係教學之外, 佢真係一個好有心嘅Prof, 聽得出佢對解決香港空氣污染真係好有抱負, 係用學術知識解決空氣污染之外, 佢有講過少少點樣有效地用一啲行政/公眾諮詢手段改變政府嘅policy-making, 都幾inspiring
